comment.author: 66722821@N00
comment._content: Unusual for the chap in naval uniform in the centre.

comment.author: 66722821@N00
comment._content: And particularly odd as the GI- code belonged to a heavy bomber unit (622 Sqn RAF).

comment.author: 74498019@N03
comment._content: No other info about this particular specimen in that awkward psition in that particural place? Was is crash landed? Or was the prop damaged by other causes? The guy walking away towards the left, which nationality is he? The service cap looks like Russian to me.

comment.author: 66722821@N00
comment._content:
I thought that too for a second but the only UK fighters to fly in the USSR in British colours were Hurricanes (and in the snow!)

The Spitfires in the south and in PVO units all had red stars applied in Iran first.

comment.author: 49487266@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/broadbottom] This image didn't have any additional information with it...we will try to find out a bit more!
comment.authorname: San Diego Air & Space Museum Archives
